title: Make the Call
text:
This book helps entrepreneurs build the habits of mind and tools of reasoning they need to make smart decisions under uncertainty. It is designed to guide anyone seeking better judgment in the face of incomplete information.
You’ll learn to:

Understand different types of uncertainty
Explore rational, empirical, and spiritual ways of knowing
Use data, models, and expert insight as sources of evidence
Apply Bayesian reasoning and decision frameworks
Develop the judgment and faith required to act wisely

Let’s get to work.

crumbs: 2  Making the Call

title: Part I: Knowing and Deciding in Uncertainty
text:
Entrepreneurship starts with uncertainty — not as a problem to be avoided, but as the very terrain we walk. In this section, you’ll learn to recognize the difference between uncertainty and risk, explore how knowledge is formed, and develop the habits of mind needed to move forward even when you don’t have all the answers.
We’ll cover:

The nature of uncertainty (aleatory vs. epistemic)
What it means to know (and why belief matters)
How different epistemologies shape your reasoning
Why judgment and faith are not weaknesses, but strengths
crumbs: Part I: Knowing and Deciding in Uncertainty

title: Part II: Asking the Right Questions
text:
Before you can act wisely, you have to know what to ask. This section focuses on how entrepreneurs identify the most urgent unknowns, shape meaningful questions, and generate smart, informed hunches. We’ll also explore the value of exploration before jumping to solutions.
We’ll cover:

How to find the questions that matter most
Turning unknowns into testable ideas
The role of abduction and intuition
Why premature hypotheses can backfire
crumbs: Part II: Asking the Right Questions

title: Part III: Gathering Evidence from the World
text:
Once you know what you’re asking, it’s time to go looking for answers. This section explores the wide world of evidence: public data, private data, customer conversations, AI, models, financials, and more. We’ll treat each as a way of knowing — not just a source of facts.
We’ll cover:

Where to find useful, credible data
When to trust experts, models, and machines
What customers can tell you — and what they can’t
How to use accounting and structure as strategic insight
crumbs: Part III: Gathering Evidence from the World

title: Part IV: Judging, Deciding, and Acting
text:
Knowing is not enough. You have to make the call. This section is about synthesizing what you’ve learned, evaluating the credibility of your evidence, updating your beliefs, and stepping forward — not with certainty, but with confidence grounded in knowledge and good judgment.
We’ll cover:

Bayesian reasoning in action
How to assess credibility and decide what counts
Decision rules, thresholds, and value of information
When to act, pivot, or stop
crumbs: Part IV: Judging, Deciding, and Acting

title: Part V: Becoming Someone Who Knows and Acts Well
text:
Smart decisions don’t come from perfect data — they come from wise decision-makers. In this final section, we focus on who you are becoming: someone who integrates knowledge, judgment, and faith. We’ll explore lifelong learning, belief revision, and the spiritual side of entrepreneurship.
We’ll cover:

How faith and revelation inform decision-making
Building habits of judgment and epistemic humility
Becoming a leader of faith, intellect, and character
Where to go from here
crumbs: Part V: Becoming Someone Who Knows and Acts Well
